subsection.title: Building a strategic plan for conversation and community integration

body.p: As with all technical documentation projects, you should plan before implementing any changes to your documentation or approach. However, when trying out social media tools, you need to be willing to spend time experimenting. Grassrootsgrassroots efforts efforts that fly under managementmanagement buy-in’s radar for a while might give you the biggest payback.

Beth KanterKanter, Beth, a social media consultant to non-profits, describes participation in social media as having five social mediaphases for implementingphases: listen, participate, generate buzz, share content, and create community.
http://beth.typepad.com/beths_blog/2008/10/how-much-time-d.html A simplification for our approach involves four phases:

ul.li: Second, participate in the conversations (and continue to listen).
Fourth, lead the way by offering a platform for conversations to occur.

body.p: A conversation enabler will work best in the first two phases. A conversation instigator can work in all the phases. I believe this phased approach yields better results than jumping straight to offering a platform. You may notice that I skipped over Kanter, BethBeth Kanter’s third phase where she suggests that you should generate buzz. I don’t think that generating buzz or media attention is necessarily the realm of technical documentationintegrating with community-based contenttechnical documentation, though it might be if you’re a lone writer bridging the gap in technical marketing documentation.
